data.title: Robert Lepage's 887 shows brilliant stagecraft, deft balance of personal and political
data.text:
Article content

In 887, however, he turns inward to tell his own story, setting it in an unremarkable apartment building at 887 Murray Ave. in Quebec City. That’s where Lepage grew up, jockeying for space in the three-bedroom unit with his parents, three siblings, and a grandmother suffering from dementia. Young Robert had to share a bedroom with his sisters while his brother was relegated to the couch.

Written, designed and directed by Lepage with his ingenious team at Ex Machina, the play’s dramatic tension revolves around Lepage’s efforts to memorize the fiery poem Speak White by Michèle Lalonde for a commemorative event in 2010.

The mental work is a challenge for the adult Lepage, which leads him to reminisce about his childhood and the nature of memory, touching on the people and events that shaped him. Many of the events have a place in history, including the Queen’s 1964 visit to Quebec City, Charles de Gaulle’s infamous “Vive le Québec libre” speech, the rise of the FLQ and the implementation of the War Measures Act.

Originally conceived in French, the play was first staged at the National Arts Centre in 2016, with English surtitles added to just a couple of performances. This run is aimed at English-speaking audiences, and will be an eye-opener for Anglos who don’t have a vivid memory of the charged atmosphere of the country’s political situation in the late ’60s and early ’70s. In that context, the play provides a valuable history lesson, along with a reminder of the potentially destructive consequences of oppression.

Article content

Also effective is the range of storytelling techniques. Performed solo, it could have resembled a run-of-the-mill TED Talk if not for Lepage’s masterful stagecraft. The focal point is an intricately constructed, multi-purpose box that serves as a miniature apartment building, a modern kitchen and a vintage diner, to name a few of the transformations that are executed by little more than a light tap or a slight push. It’s the ultimate dollhouse, and an essential part of the success of the production.

In addition to the archival material of old newspapers, family photos and grainy film footage, Lepage also uses tiny figurines, hand-shadow puppetry, the video-capture feature of his smartphone, and some animation, including one brilliant, video game-inspired view of the activity in the apartment building. Another effective piece of whimsy is the fact that his father’s cab is represented by a remote control car.

Lepage’s relationship with his father, who spent long hours away from home driving the cab, is portrayed as a bittersweet one that’s full of longing. He’s haunted by his father’s favourite song, the Nancy Sinatra version of Bang Bang, and revisits its eerie theme throughout the piece, leaving audiences with a sombre earworm that captures the gut-wrenching emotional struggle of this heartfelt story. Add to that the expertly engineered set, the deft balance between personal and political, and you’ve got a play that every Canadian should see at least once.
